(SLDG) method — 1D

Semi-Lagrangian Discountinuous Galerkin -- 1 D

Equation description

One-dimensional transport equation

Firstly, we consider the one-dimensional transport equation:

{ut+(a(x,t)⋅u)x=0,x∈[xa,xb]u(x,0)=u0(x) \begin{equation} \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} u_t + (a(x,t)\cdot u)_x = 0, x\in [x_a,x_b] \\ u(x,0) = u_0(x) \\ \end{array} \right. \end{equation} {ut​+(a(x,t)⋅u)x​=0,x∈[xa​,xb​]u(x,0)=u0​(x)​​​

  • a(x,t)a(x,t)a(x,t) is continuous, and divides in xa=x12<x32<...<xM+12=xbx_a = x_{\frac{1}{2}}<x_{\frac{3}{2}}< ... < x_{M+\frac{1}{2}} = x_bxa​=x21​​<x23​​<...<xM+21​​=xb​
  • For jjj-iterm, denoted Ij=[xj−12,xj+12]I_j = [x_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}]Ij​=[xj−21​​,xj+21​​]
  • Center point: xj=xj−12+xj+122x_j = \frac{x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}+x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}}{2}xj​=2xj−21​​+xj+21​​​
  • Iterm length: Δxj=xj+12−xj−12\Delta x_j = x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}-x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}Δxj​=xj+21​​−xj−21​​
  • The domain is partitioned by non-overlapping intervals, Ω=∪jIj\Omega=\cup_{j}I_{j}Ω=∪j​Ij​.
  • The mesh size is denoted h=max⁡jΔxjh = \max_{j}\Delta x_{j}h=maxj​Δxj​.
  • n-th time level with Δtn=tn+1−tn\Delta t^{n} = t^{n+1}-t^{n}Δtn=tn+1−tn

Approximation space

Approximation space (近似空间)

Vhk={vh:vh∣Ij∈Pk(Ij)}Ψi(x) V_{h}^{k} = \{v_h : v_h|_{I_j}\in P^k(I_j)\} \Psi_{i}(x) Vhk​={vh​:vh​∣Ij​​∈Pk(Ij​)}Ψi​(x)

  • k≥0k \geq 0k≥0
  • Pk(Ij)P^k(I_j)Pk(Ij​) denotes the set of Orthnogonal Legendre polynomials of degree at the most kkk over IjI_jIj​ interval.
  • If k=0k = 0k=0, the scheme formulated below problated below reduces to a first order SL finite volumme scheme.

Introduce the test function ψ(x,t)\psi(x,t)ψ(x,t), satisfying the boundary conditions ψ(x,tn+1)=Ψ(x∈Pk(Ij)\psi(x,t^{n+1}) = \Psi(x \in P^{k}(I_j)ψ(x,tn+1)=Ψ(x∈Pk(Ij​), yields the following expression:

ψt+a(x,t)ψx=0,t∈[tn,tn+1] \begin{equation} \psi_t + a(x,t)\psi_x = 0,t\in [t^n,t^{n+1}] \end{equation} ψt​+a(x,t)ψx​=0,t∈[tn,tn+1]​​

The preceding equations (2), presented in adjective form, maintain a constant solution along a characteristic trajectory. Subsequently, as demonstrated in, it can be established that:

ddt∫Ij~(t)u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=0 \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt}\int_{\widetilde{I_{j}}(t)} u(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx = 0 \end{equation} dtd​∫Ij​​(t)​u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=0​​

where Ij~(t){\widetilde{I_{j}}(t)}Ij​​(t) is a dynamic intervel bounded by characteristcs emanating from cell boundaries of IjI_jIj​ at t=tn+1t=t^{n+1}t=tn+1.

Prove for (3) One-dimentional Reynolds transport theorem

According to one-dimentional Reynolds transport theorem,

ddx∫a(t)b(t)f(x,t)dx=∫a(t)b(t)∂f(x,t)∂tdx+(∂b(t)∂tf(b(t),t)−∂a(t)∂tf(a(t),t)) \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dx}\int_{a(t)}^{b(t)}f(x,t)dx = \int_{a(t)}^{b(t)}\frac{\partial f(x,t)}{\partial t}dx + (\frac{\partial b(t)}{\partial t}f(b(t),t) - \frac{\partial a(t)}{\partial t}f(a(t),t)) \end{equation} dxd​∫a(t)b(t)​f(x,t)dx=∫a(t)b(t)​∂t∂f(x,t)​dx+(∂t∂b(t)​f(b(t),t)−∂t∂a(t)​f(a(t),t))​​

Then, along the characteristic line γ:dxdt=a(x,t)\gamma:\frac{dx}{dt} = a(x,t)γ:dtdx​=a(x,t), we can have:

ddt∫Ij~(t)u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=[dxdtu(x,t)ψ(x,t)]∣x=xj−12x=xj+12+∫Ij(t)ut(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx+∫Ij(t)u(x,t)ψt(x,t)dx \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt}\int_{\widetilde{I_j}(t)}u(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx = \bigg[\frac{dx}{dt}u(x,t)\psi(x,t) \bigg]\Bigg|_{x = x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}}^{x = x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}} + \int_{I_j(t)}u_t(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx + \int_{I_j(t)}u(x,t)\psi_t(x,t)dx \end{equation} dtd​∫Ij​​(t)​u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=[dtdx​u(x,t)ψ(x,t)]​x=xj−21​​x=xj+21​​​+∫Ij​(t)​ut​(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx+∫Ij​(t)​u(x,t)ψt​(x,t)dx​​

ddt∫Ij~(t)u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=auψ∣x=xj+12−auψ∣x=xj−12−∫Ij(t)∂(a⋅u)∂xψ(x,t)dx−∫Ij(t)u⋅aψx \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt}\int_{\widetilde{I_j}(t)}u(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx = au\psi|_{x=x_{j+\frac{1}{2}}} - au\psi|_{x = x_{j - \frac{1}{2}}} - \int_{I_j(t)}\frac{\partial (a \cdot u)}{\partial{x}}\psi(x,t)dx - \int_{I_j(t)} u\cdot a \psi_x \end{equation} dtd​∫Ij​​(t)​u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=auψ∣x=xj+21​​​−auψ∣x=xj−21​​​−∫Ij​(t)​∂x∂(a⋅u)​ψ(x,t)dx−∫Ij​(t)​u⋅aψx​​​

ddt∫Ij~(t)u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=0 \begin{equation} \frac{d}{dt}\int_{\widetilde{I_j}(t)}u(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx = 0 \end{equation} dtd​∫Ij​​(t)​u(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=0​​

where ut(x,t)=du(x,t)dtu_t(x,t) = \frac{d u(x,t)}{dt}ut​(x,t)=dtdu(x,t)​ and dxdt=a(a,t)\frac{dx}{dt} = a(a,t)dtdx​=a(a,t), then

∂x∂ududt=a(a,t)→dudt=a(x,t)∂u∂t \frac{\partial{x}}{\partial{u}} \frac{du}{dt} = a(a,t) \xrightarrow{} \frac{du}{dt} = a(x,t)\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{t}} ∂u∂x​dtdu​=a(a,t)​dtdu​=a(x,t)∂t∂u​

∫Ij(t)ut(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=∫Ij(t)∂(a⋅u)∂xψ(x,t)dx \int_{I_j(t)}u_t(x,t)\psi(x,t)dx = \int_{I_j(t)}\frac{\partial (a \cdot u)}{\partial{x}}\psi(x,t)dx ∫Ij​(t)​ut​(x,t)ψ(x,t)dx=∫Ij​(t)​∂x∂(a⋅u)​ψ(x,t)dx

Given un∈Vhku^n \in V_h^kun∈Vhk​, we seek un+1∈Vhku^{n+1}\in V_h^kun+1∈Vhk​, such that for ∀Ψ∈Pk(Ij),j=1,...,k\forall \Psi \in P^k (I_j),j=1,...,k∀Ψ∈Pk(Ij​),j=1,...,k。 An SL time discretization of equation(3) leads to

∫Ijun+1(x,t)Ψdx=∫Ij∗u(x,tn)ψ(x.tn)dx \begin{equation} \int_{I_j}u^{n+1}(x,t)\Psi dx = \int_{I^{*}_{j}}u(x,t^n)\psi(x.t^n)dx \end{equation} ∫Ij​​un+1(x,t)Ψdx=∫Ij∗​​u(x,tn)ψ(x.tn)dx​​

where Ij∗=[xj−12∗,xj+12∗]I^{*}_{j} = [x^{*}_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x^{*}_{j+\frac{1}{2}}]Ij∗​=[xj−21​∗​,xj+21​∗​] with xj±12∗x^{*}_{j\pm \frac{1}{2}}xj±21​∗​ being the foots of trajectory emanating from (xj±12∗,tn+1)(x^{*}_{j\pm \frac{1}{2}},t^{n+1})(xj±21​∗​,tn+1) at the time tnt^ntn. Then, update the numerical solution un+1u^{n+1}un+1.

Implementation

Step 1

Initially, we select k+1k+1k+1 interpolation points xj,px_{j,p}xj,p​, where p=0,...,kp = 0,...,kp=0,...,k(此时0到k就正好是k+1个), empolying methods like Gauss-Lobatto points within the interval IjI_jIj​.

Gauss-Lobatto

Utilizing Gaussian quadrature with a weighting function W(x)=1W(x)=1W(x)=1, encompassing the endpoints of the interval [−1,1][-1,1][−1,1], involves a total of n abscissas, resulting in r=n−2r=n-2r=n−2 free abscissas. The abscissas are symmetric about the origin, and the general formula is given by:

∫−11f(x)dx=w1f(−1)+wnf(1)+∑i=2n−1wif(xi). \begin{equation} \int_{-1}^{1}f(x)dx = w_1 f(-1) + w_n f(1) + \sum_{i=2}^{n-1}w_if(x_i). \end{equation} ∫−11​f(x)dx=w1​f(−1)+wn​f(1)+i=2∑n−1​wi​f(xi​).​​

The unrestricted abscissas xix_ixi​ for i=2,...,n−1i=2, ..., n-1i=2,...,n−1 correspond to the roots of the derivative Pn−1′(x)P_{n-1}^{'}(x)Pn−1′​(x), where P(x)P(x)P(x) represents a Legendre polynomial. The weights associated with these unrestricted abscissas are:

wi=−2n(1−xi2)Pn+1′′Pm′(xi)=2n(n−1)[Pn−1(xi)]2 \begin{equation} w_i = - \frac{2n}{(1-x_i^2)P^{''}_{n+1}P^{'}_{m}(x_i)}= \frac{2}{n(n-1)[P_{n-1}(x_i)]^2} \end{equation} wi​=−(1−xi2​)Pn+1′′​Pm′​(xi​)2n​=n(n−1)[Pn−1​(xi​)]22​​​

and the endpoint are wi,n2n(n−1)w_{i,n}\frac{2}{n(n-1)}wi,n​n(n−1)2​.

Subsequencetly, we determine the footpoints xj,q∗x^{*}_{j,q}xj,q∗​ through numerical solutions to the trajectory equation.

dx(t)dt=a(x(t),t), with x(tn+1)=xj,q \begin{equation} \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = a(x(t),t), \text{ with } x(t^{n+1}) = x_{j,q} \end{equation} dtdx(t)​=a(x(t),t), with x(tn+1)=xj,q​​​

    ! assemble gauss lobatto of an upstream element
    ! prepare for interpolating the test function.
    do i = 1,nx
        ! consider an upstream element
        p => element_star(i)
        pe => element(i)
        
        if( nk>0 )then
            p%xgl_star(1) =  vertex_star(i)%coor
            p%xgl_star(nk+1) = vertex_star(i+1)%coor
            !
            if( nk>1 )then
                pe%xgl(1) = vertex(i)%coor
                pe%xgl(nk+1) = vertex(i+1)%coor

                do ii = 2,nk
                    pe%xgl(ii) = pe%xgl(1)+( 1.0/2. + gau_lob(ii,1) )*(  pe%xgl(nk+1)-pe%xgl(1) )

                    call runge_kutta( pe%xgl(ii) , p%xgl_star(ii)   ,dt)
                enddo

            endif
        endif
    enddo

Runge-Kutta 4

Achieved using the Runge-Kutta method as follow,

{xj,q∗=xj,q−Δt6(k1+2k2+2k3+k4)k1=a(xj,q,tn+1),k2=a(xj,q−Δt2k1,tn+12), where tn+12=tn+12Δtk3=a(xj,q−Δt2k2,tn+12), where tn+12=tn+12Δtk4=a(xj,q−Δtk3,tn) \begin{equation} \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} x^{*}_{j,q}=x_{j,q}-\frac{\Delta t}{6}(k_1+2k_2+2k_3+k_4) \\ k_1 = a(x_{j,q},t^{n+1}),\\ k_2 = a(x_{j,q}-\frac{\Delta t}{2}k_1,t^{n+\frac{1}{2}}), \text{ where } t^{n+\frac{1}{2}} = t^{n}+\frac{1}{2}\Delta t\\ k_3 = a(x_{j,q}-\frac{\Delta t}{2}k_2, t^{n+\frac{1}{2}}),\text{ where } t^{n+\frac{1}{2}} = t^{n}+\frac{1}{2}\Delta t\\ k_4 = a(x_{j,q}-\Delta t k_3, t^{n}) \end{array} \right. \end{equation} ⎩⎨⎧​xj,q∗​=xj,q​−6Δt​(k1​+2k2​+2k3​+k4​)k1​=a(xj,q​,tn+1),k2​=a(xj,q​−2Δt​k1​,tn+21​), where tn+21​=tn+21​Δtk3​=a(xj,q​−2Δt​k2​,tn+21​), where tn+21​=tn+21​Δtk4​=a(xj,q​−Δtk3​,tn)​​​

ahieves fifth-order accuracy O(h5)O(h^5)O(h5). Since for RK4, the local truncation error is on the order of O(h5)O(h^5)O(h5), where hhh is the step size.

Step 2

Recalling that the test function ψ(x,t)\psi(x,t)ψ(x,t) resolves the final-value problem and consequently remains constant along the characteristics i.e., ψ(xj,q∗)=Ψ(xj,q)\psi(x^{*}_{j,q}) = \Psi(x_{j,q})ψ(xj,q∗​)=Ψ(xj,q​). Our next step is to ascertain the unique polynomial ψ∗(x)\psi^{*}(x)ψ∗(x) of degree kkk. This polynomial is chosen such that it interpolates ψ(x,tn)\psi(x,t^n)ψ(x,tn) with the pairs (xj,q∗,Ψ(xj,q))(x^{*}_{j,q},\Psi(x_{j,q}))(xj,q∗​,Ψ(xj,q​)) for q=0,…,kq=0, \ldots, kq=0,…,k.

we assume that ψ∗(x)=a0+a1x+a2x2+…+akxk\psi^{*}(x)=a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \ldots + a_k x^{k}ψ∗(x)=a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+…+ak​xk, and ψ∗(x)\psi^{*}(x)ψ∗(x) satisfies,

{a0+a1xj,0∗+a2xj,0∗2+…+akxj,0∗k=Ψ(xj,0)a0+a1xj,1∗+a2xj,1∗2+…+akxj,1∗k=Ψ(xj,1)⋮a0+a1xj,k∗+a2xj,k∗2+…+akxj,k∗k=Ψ(xj,k) \begin{equation} \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} a_0 + a_1 x^{*}_{j,0} + a_2 x^{*\quad2}_{j,0} + \ldots + a_k x^{*\quad k}_{j,0} = \Psi(x_{j,0})\\ a_0 + a_1 x^{*}_{j,1} + a_2 x^{*\quad2}_{j,1} + \ldots + a_k x^{*\quad k}_{j,1} = \Psi(x_{j,1})\\ \vdots \\ a_0 + a_1 x^{*}_{j,k} + a_2 x^{*\quad2}_{j,k} + \ldots + a_k x^{*\quad k}_{j,k} = \Psi(x_{j,k})\\ \end{array} \right. \end{equation} ⎩⎨⎧​a0​+a1​xj,0∗​+a2​xj,0∗2​+…+ak​xj,0∗k​=Ψ(xj,0​)a0​+a1​xj,1∗​+a2​xj,1∗2​+…+ak​xj,1∗k​=Ψ(xj,1​)⋮a0​+a1​xj,k∗​+a2​xj,k∗2​+…+ak​xj,k∗k​=Ψ(xj,k​)​​​

Or we need to use the orthogonal polynomial 1d form or Legendre polynomials

Legendre polynomials in [-1,1]

ξ=2(x−xj)hj∈[−1,1],∀x∈Ij \begin{equation} \xi = \frac{2(x-x_j)}{h_j} \in[-1,1], \forall x\in I_{j} \end{equation} ξ=hj​2(x−xj​)​∈[−1,1],∀x∈Ij​​​

The first several polynomials are defined as

p0(ξ)=1,p1(ξ)=ξ,p2(ξ)=12(3ξ2−1),p3(ξ)=12(5ξ3−3ξ) p_0(\xi) = 1, p_1(\xi) = \xi, p_2(\xi) = \frac{1}{2}(3\xi^{2}-1), \\ p_3(\xi) = \frac{1}{2}(5\xi^{3}-3\xi) p0​(ξ)=1,p1​(ξ)=ξ,p2​(ξ)=21​(3ξ2−1),p3​(ξ)=21​(5ξ3−3ξ)

In the each interval IjI_{j}Ij​, we can take the local functions {ψl(x)}l=0l=k\{\psi_{l}(x)\}_{l=0}^{l=k}{ψl​(x)}l=0l=k​

ψl(x)=pl(ξ),x∈Ij \psi_{l}(x) = p_{l}(\xi),x\in I_{j} ψl​(x)=pl​(ξ),x∈Ij​

Then we can let,

A=[1xj,0∗xj,0∗2⋯xj,0∗k1xj,1∗xj,1∗2⋯xj,1∗k⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮1xj,k∗xj,k∗2⋯xj,k∗k] A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & x^{*}_{j,0} & x^{*\quad2}_{j,0} &\cdots& x^{*\quad k}_{j,0} \\ 1 & x^{*}_{j,1} & x^{*\quad2}_{j,1} &\cdots& x^{*\quad k}_{j,1} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots\\ 1 & x^{*}_{j,k} & x^{*\quad2}_{j,k} &\cdots& x^{*\quad k}_{j,k} \\ \end{bmatrix} A=​11⋮1​xj,0∗​xj,1∗​⋮xj,k∗​​xj,0∗2​xj,1∗2​⋮xj,k∗2​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​xj,0∗k​xj,1∗k​⋮xj,k∗k​​​

X=[a0a1⋮ak],B=[Ψ(xj,0)Ψ(xj,1)⋮Ψ(xj,k)] X = \begin{bmatrix} a_0 \\ a_1 \\ \vdots \\ a_k \end{bmatrix}, B = \begin{bmatrix} \Psi(x_{j,0})\\\Psi(x_{j,1})\\\vdots\\\Psi(x_{j,k})\\ \end{bmatrix} X=​a0​a1​⋮ak​​​,B=​Ψ(xj,0​)Ψ(xj,1​)⋮Ψ(xj,k​)​​

Then system (11) can be expressed in matrix from AX=BAX=BAX=B. Then we need to find the coefficients a0,a1,⋯aka_0,a_1,\cdots a_ka0​,a1​,⋯ak​ of the ψ∗(x)\psi^{*}(x)ψ∗(x).

Step 3

Detect interval/sub-intervals within Ij∗=∪lIj,l∗I^{*}_{j} = \cup_{l}I^{*}_{j,l}Ij∗​=∪l​Ij,l∗​, which are the intersections bewteen Ij∗I^{*}_{j}Ij∗​ and the grid elements(l is the index for sub-interval). Here lll serves as the index for the sub-interval. For each interval, there may exist two sub-intervals: Ij,1∗=[xj−12∗,xj−12]I^{*}_{j,1}=[x^{*}_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x_{j-\frac{1}{2}}]Ij,1∗​=[xj−21​∗​,xj−21​​] and Ij,2=[xj−12,xj+12∗]I_{j,2}=[x_{j-\frac{1}{2}},x^{*}_{j+\frac{1}{2}}]Ij,2​=[xj−21​​,xj+21​∗​], Like the picture below.

Firstly, for each result of xj−12∗x^{*}_{j-\frac{1}{2}}xj−21​∗​ or xj+12∗x^{*}_{j+\frac{1}{2}}xj+21​∗​ we record the distance with the original start point. Then, we calculate the number of subinterval by (vertex_star(i)%coor-xleft)/dx.

do i = 1 ,nx+1
    call runge_kutta( vertex(i)%coor ,  vertex_star(i)%coor  ,dt)
    !ceiling 是向上取整
    vertex_star(i)%id = ceiling( (vertex_star(i)%coor-xleft)/dx )
enddo

And in the implementation, we use a new data structure and create a pointer to obtain all x∗x^{*}x∗.

do i = 1,nx
    ! consider an upstream element
    p => element_star(i)
    p%point_origin = vertex_star(i)
    p%point_end = vertex_star(i+1)

    call search_segment(p)
enddo

After that, we use the sgement_search function, to get all subinterval of an upstream element.

mx = p%point_end%id - p%point_origin%id ! mx也表示x*中有几个点

p%point_inter(0) = p%point_origin !x* 的起始点
p%point_inter(1+mx) = p%point_end !如果x* 都在一个interval里，那么mx = 0, 点就是 p%point_inter(1)
p%nsub = mx+1 !x* 有几个subinterval

if(mx .ne. 0)then
    do kk = 1 , mx
        inter = p%point_origin%id + kk !是第几个x
        p%point_inter(kk)%coor = xgrid( inter ) !通过xgrid找到x的值
        p%point_inter(kk)%id = inter !记录起始点对应的位置
    enddo
endif
!记录每一个subinterval起始点，终点&起始点对应的位置
do kk = 1 , 1 + mx
    p%segment(kk)%porigin = p%point_inter(kk-1)
    p%segment(kk)%pend = p%point_inter(kk)
    p%segment(kk)%id = p%point_inter(kk-1)%id
enddo

Finally, we obtain Ij∗=∪lIj,l∗I^{*}_{j} = \cup_{l}I^{*}_{j,l}Ij∗​=∪l​Ij,l∗​

Step 4

Using the discontinuous Galerkin method to obtain uhn+1∈Pk(Ij)u^{n+1}_{h}\in P^{k}(I_j)uhn+1​∈Pk(Ij​), such that the above equation holds for any Ψh∈Pk(Ij)\Psi_{h}\in P^{k}(I_j)Ψh​∈Pk(Ij​).

In the each interval IjI_{j}Ij​, we can take the local functions {ψl(x)}l=0l=k\{\psi_{l}(x)\}_{l=0}^{l=k}{ψl​(x)}l=0l=k​

ψl(x)=pl(ξ),x∈Ij \begin{equation} \psi_{l}(x) = p_{l}(\xi),x\in I_{j} \end{equation} ψl​(x)=pl​(ξ),x∈Ij​​​

where pl(ξ)p_{l}(\xi)pl​(ξ) is the Legendre polynomials in [−1,1][-1,1][−1,1].

The basis functions satisfy the following property:

  • L2−L^2-L2−orthogonality

∫−11pm(ξ)pn(ξ)dξ=22n+1δmn,∀m,n=0,1,...,k \begin{equation} \int_{-1}^{1}p_{m}(\xi)p_{n}(\xi)d\xi = \frac{2}{2n+1}\delta_{mn},\forall m,n = 0,1,...,k \end{equation} ∫−11​pm​(ξ)pn​(ξ)dξ=2n+12​δmn​,∀m,n=0,1,...,k​​

where δmn\delta_{mn}δmn​ is Kronecker delta,equal to 1 if m=nm = nm=n and to 0 otherwise. Then, the local basis functions {ψl(x)}\{\psi_{l}(x)\}{ψl​(x)} in IjI_{j}Ij​

∫Ijψm(x)ψn(x)dx=∫−11pm(ξ)pn(ξ)dξ⋅hj2=hj2n+1δmn \begin{equation} \int_{I_j}\psi_{m}(x)\psi_{n}(x)dx = \int_{-1}^{1}p_{m}(\xi)p_{n}(\xi)d\xi \cdot \frac{h_j}{2}= \frac{h_j}{2n+1}\delta_{mn} \end{equation} ∫Ij​​ψm​(x)ψn​(x)dx=∫−11​pm​(ξ)pn​(ξ)dξ⋅2hj​​=2n+1hj​​δmn​​​

Where hjh_jhj​ is the mesh size for sub-interval and this formula means the ψ\psiψ is linear independent.

Therefore, uhn+1=Pk(Ij)u^{n+1}_{h} = P^{k}(I_j)uhn+1​=Pk(Ij​) can be expressed with ψm\psi_mψm​

uhn+1=∑m=0kαmn+1ψm u^{n+1}_{h} = \sum_{m=0}^{k}\alpha_{m}^{n+1}\psi_m uhn+1​=m=0∑k​αmn+1​ψm​

Step 5

For uh0u^{0}_huh0​, in each element jjj, we can assume uh0=∑m=0kαm0ψn, For n=0,..,ku^{0}_{h} = \sum_{m=0}^{k} \alpha^{0}_{m}\psi_{n}, \text{ For }n=0,..,kuh0​=∑m=0k​αm0​ψn​, For n=0,..,k

(u0,ψn)=∑m=0αm0(θm,θn)=αm0hj2m+1δmn \begin{align} (u^{0},\psi_{n}) &=\sum_{m=0}\alpha_{m}^{0}(\theta_m,\theta_n) \\ &= \alpha_{m}^{0}\frac{h_j}{2m+1}\delta_{mn} \end{align} (u0,ψn​)​=m=0∑​αm0​(θm​,θn​)=αm0​2m+1hj​​δmn​​​

where we obtain (u0,ψn)(u^{0},\psi_{n})(u0,ψn​) by numerical integration,

αm0=(2m+1)(u0,ψn)hj \begin{equation} \alpha_{m}^{0} = (2m+1) \frac{(u^{0},\psi_{n})}{h_j} \end{equation} αm0​=(2m+1)hj​(u0,ψn​)​​​

Step 6

For each element jjj, we have

∫Ijuhn+1Ψhdx=∫Ij∗uhnψndx=∑l∫Ij,luh∗ψ∗dx \begin{equation} \int_{I_j} u^{n+1}_h \Psi_h dx = \int_{I^{*}_{j}}u^{n}_{h}\psi^{n}dx = \sum_{l}\int_{I_{j,l}}u^{*}_{h}\psi^{*}dx \end{equation} ∫Ij​​uhn+1​Ψh​dx=∫Ij∗​​uhn​ψndx=l∑​∫Ij,l​​uh∗​ψ∗dx​​

Note that

mstj=∫Ijψsψtdx=hj2s+1δstbsj=∑l∫Ij,luhnψs∗dx \begin{aligned} &m^{j}_{st} = \int_{I_j}\psi_s \psi_t dx = \frac{h_j}{2s+1}\delta_{st} \\ &b_{s}^{j} = \sum_{l}\int_{I_{j,l}}u^n_h\psi_s^* dx \\ \end{aligned} ​mstj​=∫Ij​​ψs​ψt​dx=2s+1hj​​δst​bsj​=l∑​∫Ij,l​​uhn​ψs∗​dx​

The matrix is

[m00jm01j⋯m0kjm10jm11j⋯m1kj⋮⋮⋯⋮mk0jmk1j⋯mkkj][α0j,n+1α1j,n+1⋮αkj,n+1]=[b0jb1j⋮bkj] \begin{bmatrix} m_{00}^{j} & m_{01}^{j} &\cdots &m_{0k}^{j} \\ m_{10}^{j} & m_{11}^{j} &\cdots &m_{1k}^{j} \\ \vdots & \vdots &\cdots &\vdots \\ m_{k0}^{j} & m_{k1}^{j} &\cdots &m_{kk}^{j} \\ \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \alpha_{0}^{j,n+1} \\ \alpha_{1}^{j,n+1} \\ \vdots \\ \alpha_{k}^{j,n+1} \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} b{0}^{j} \\ b{1}^{j} \\ \vdots \\ b{k}^{j} \\ \end{bmatrix} ​m00j​m10j​⋮mk0j​​m01j​m11j​⋮mk1j​​⋯⋯⋯⋯​m0kj​m1kj​⋮mkkj​​​​α0j,n+1​α1j,n+1​⋮αkj,n+1​​​=​b0jb1j⋮bkj​​

Step 7

Mj=[mstj](k+1)×(k+1), for s,t=0,⋯ ,kBj=[bsj](k+1)×1, for s=0,⋯ ,kXj=[αsj,n+1](k+1)×1, for s=0,⋯ ,k \begin{aligned} &M^j = [m^{j}_{st}]_{(k+1)\times (k+1)}, \text{ for }s,t=0,\cdots,k\\ &B^j = [b_{s}^{j}]_{(k+1)\times 1}, \text{ for }s=0,\cdots,k\\ &X^j = [\alpha^{j,n+1}_{s}]_{(k+1)\times 1}, \text{ for }s=0,\cdots,k \end{aligned} ​Mj=[mstj​](k+1)×(k+1)​, for s,t=0,⋯,kBj=[bsj​](k+1)×1​, for s=0,⋯,kXj=[αsj,n+1​](k+1)×1​, for s=0,⋯,k​

Then the global stiffness matrix is

M=[M10⋯00M2⋯0⋮⋮⋯⋮00⋯MN],Xn+1=[X1X2⋮XN],B[B1B2⋮BN] M = \begin{bmatrix} M^{1} & 0 &\cdots &0 \\ 0 & M^{2} &\cdots &0 \\ \vdots & \vdots &\cdots &\vdots \\ 0 & 0 &\cdots &M^{N} \\ \end{bmatrix} \\ , X^{n+1} = \begin{bmatrix} X^1 \\ X^2 \\ \vdots \\ X^N \\ \end{bmatrix} , B\begin{bmatrix} B^1 \\ B^2 \\ \vdots \\ B^N \\ \end{bmatrix} M=​M10⋮0​0M2⋮0​⋯⋯⋯⋯​00⋮MN​​,Xn+1=​X1X2⋮XN​​,B​B1B2⋮BN​​

Finally, we can solve the linear equatiuns systems

MXn+1=B \begin{equation} MX^{n+1} = B \end{equation} MXn+1=B​​
